etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in William Turner (d. 1568), naturalist and religious controversialist. From hart + wort, after German Hirtzwurtz

definitions: Originally: any of various umbelliferous plants used medicinally; especially the herbaceous plants Laserpitium latifolium, L. siser, Seseli tortuosum, and Levisticum officinale, and the shrub Bupleurum fruticosum. In later use: specifically any member of the genus Tordylium (family Apiaceae (Umbelliferae)), comprising herbaceous plants native to southern Europe (and grown or occasionally naturalized elsewhere); especially (more fully "great hartwort") T. maximum.

notes.text: Originally applied mainly to plants known to 16th and 17th century herbalists by the Latin name of seseli (now redistributed to many modern genera).
